Good video overall, but the N1 explosion is not the largest man-made, non-nuclear explosion.  The munition ship explosion in Halifax, NS, Canada post WW1 was much larger, and (according to the wikipedia page on non nuclear explosions)  the N1 was only about #7 at the time of the video release (Beirut also being larger).  Given the tragic nature of most of these explosions I feel it is disrespectful to call the N1 the largest.  I realize that was not your intention, Tim, but a correction would be appreciated.

I cringe when you say utilize. It’s not a synonym for use and it doesn’t make things sound more technical. Utilize implies you’re using something to solve a problem it wasn’t intended to solve. You wouldn’t utilize a paper clip to clip papers because that’s it’s intended purpose. You could utilize a paper clip to eject an SD card because that’s not it’s intended purpose. That’s why abutilize isn’t a word.

Btw..... a good reason NOT to destruct the rocket, considering the limited threat factor of ground based structures, is to watch and record flight characteristics after a failure occurs. For instance, the axial rotation could not have been observed if the destruction of the rocket occurred right away. The oscilating pitch was obvious, but would not have immediately pointed them to the inertial dampeners. The spinning of the rocket however around its axis did point THE INVESTIGATORS in the right direction even though the rocket itself didn't enjoy the same benefit.

Ariane V: The component, that caused the failed covernsion from 64 bit to 15bit was a reused part of the Ariane IV. At the Ariane IV the values at this sensor never left the valid number area and therefore was never checked for to big numbers. On the Ariane V on the other side, the sensor values could leave the valid range. But noboby thought about that. -- And the worst part: The sensor was only used on the launch table. After lift off it was not necassary any more. But they kept the sensor online. --> Two lessons: Always double check the sensor range iif you change something. Turn it off if you don't need it.

The Air Force found out an interesting fact, due to weight  constraints most of the structural members were made of aluminium . These parts were bolted together, as per specification the bolts were given a coating of teflon grease. When the rocket was launched the G forces caused the bolts to tighten.  Unknown to the engineers teflon and aluminium under shear stress become an explosive.  The early missiles were actually blowing themselves  up.

Oh btw Number 1 in this list isn't The Biggest Non nuclear Explosion in history the British holds that record when the biggest Ammunition Bunker exploded in I think 1942 or 1943 and it was even bigger then that Russian Rocket Explosion. The Explosion that happened at the British Ammunition Bunker was the reason the Americans started the Manhattan Project and was the reason Nuclear Bombs got invented. Even to this day there's over 9000 unexploded bombs under the ground of the ammunition bunker but some people think there could be even more then 9000. The reason why the British Government don't try to clean it up is because it's far to dangerous so they decided to cover all known entrances up that didn't get destroyed in the initial explosion.

Without Losing Human Life in Science our Knowledge can not grow. But however I do think you can do a video on that and still respect the people who gave their life's for Space and for the Human Race. If Human Life never got lost Rocket Engineering would of never been this safe in today's world. It's because of Humans who Lost their Lifes that Rocket Engineering has became alot more safe and We understand alot more and hopefully Space Companies never Cut Corners again just to save time and money. The reason why SpaceX is so successful is because the Engineers fully understand what can happen if you mess up so they spend alot of time checking to make sure everything in the engines are fully set and SpaceX also purposely blown up a 50 or 60 Million Dollar Rocket just to test the FailSafe system to make sure it actually works just in case they ever needed to use it if real humans were in danger.

First video: ran out of hydraulic fluid? ehhh sorry bro, WRONG, hydraulic systems do not USE hydraulic fluid and just discard it. Hydraulic systems are enclosed systems (either vented or closed) that have a reservoir and use the same fluid circulating from the reservoir to the actuators and then returning back to the reservoir, constantly recycling itself. So nah, they didn't run out of fluid unless they had a leak somewhere which they did not indicate. So with all that said, i think they just over corrected and F'd it up bro 😉👍
Second one: ditto, they F'd it up, when it touched down it was not straight up, prolly bent the landing arms and it fell over from the stress.

In fact i've seen most of these landing disasters and 99% of them were from miscalculations causing the booster to land improperly ending in them falling over and exploding from the impact rupturing the internal fuel tanks etc, sparks igniting the fuel and boom!

I will say though, the concept thinking that guided them into thinking they can reuse a booster is innovative, the fact they can recover a booster like this is rather amazing, they're bound to break a few eggs before they get it more right than wrong.

though it was not a float to in conversion problem - it was an int overflow problem due to the fact that the software was origianlly designed for the older and weaker engine.

The maximum range of fix point integers was not adapted, so the whole thing resulted in aninteger wrap around at a certain velocity.

It would be a terrible failute to use floating point in highly safety relevant software. This is why fied point arithmetic with integers is still used when SW has to be safe and reliable ...

In the case of an arrow there should be correspondance bewteen components, ie an arrow on both.

My father was a lead man building the F-1 engines for the Saturn 5. I am now 63. My dad has been gone 20 years. As a kid I knew a lot about the engines, but recently I have been curious.

I found some amazing things, which I checked from multiple sources. I knew they were powerful. but at that time, with the US population as it was, the five F-1 engines launching the rocket, for the two and a half minutes they burned, could have powered the entire USA. 300 gigawatts total output. But they sucked 15,000 gallons of fuel per second, which is why the rocket was so big.
Each engine produced the power of 17 Hoover Dams. 60 gigawatts. One engine could, at the time, power the entire UK.

585,000 HP per engine. 7.5 million lbs of thrust total. When I was a kid I was VERY focused on the news reports of the launches. Often they would mention the Richter reading in NY City, too low to feel, but these engines rattled the whole East Coast. I joke with people. My father retired from the Santa Fe Railway. I say that one of the locomotives he rebuilt would melt in the flame of an F-1.

For that first Atlas failure, Range Safety lets the rockets fly to their launch limit envelope before pushing the destruct.  That way the rocket manufacturer can get as much data as possible to help them fix their problem(s).  The limit envelope is mission unique and is designed to insure the rocket will not impact anywhere that it could harm people.  And it is based on the potential results of any worst case failure, such as a nozzle hard-over.

Just a thought...I was 3 miles from the pad for a Space Shuttle launch; the sound/feeling when the SRB's lit off is incredible: you feel it in your chest and belly as well as hear it. An easier description of the Ariane 5 fiasco: They tested the software in simulation using data from actual Ariane 4 launches. Unfortunately the trajectory of the Ariane 5 is shallower, resulting in higher horizontal speeds in early flight. The variable holding the horizontal velocity component then overflowed causing the computers (multiple) to all see the same error. The funny part is that at the time the error occurred the flight computer software was no longer using this horizontal vector information in its flight calculations! In the event of single computer "failure" the other two systems take over. However since all the computers saw the same error, the software surrendered (insert French joke here) and the vehicle was lost.

As for Launchpad 16 ... believe it or not, but fuel isn't that great a bomb building material as it is so easily combustible using up a lot of its potential energy in the fire and not expansion / pressure waves... real explosives are harder to detonate but contain even more energy density than the rocket fuels used, which is set free in an even more rapid cascade style reaction. So what you end up with in a fuel explosion is a spectacular fireball, but despite the size and seeming violence of the plume it hasn't really all that much explosive power.
I'd blame Hollywood for that, as they have used fuelfed "explosions" (gasoline is still popular although plantpollen and other flour like substances have sometimes replaced it, similar effect as they mostly look fiery due to the high combustion surface in a good mix of substrate and air) for decades to replace more authentic depictions of bombs (not to forget how they caused thousands of cardeaths by making people believe any fire will immediately cause a giant explosion, so they'd not go and pull people out of smouldering wrecks) and so people instinctually connect giant flameballs with powerful explosions, which they are not, at least not compared to what even small military ammunitions can do. Solid steel and concrete structures like a launchpad probably end up mostly singed and most of the work would be testing and replacing cables, electronics (sensors, cameras) and fuellines, checking any motors or movable parts and maybe freshen up the paintcoat.

A couple of things.. one... the Space-X explosion (on launch pad 40)... just an FYI... it might have never been 'experienced' before... but it was known about as this knowledge was publicly available from NASA records ... and started the conversation as to why Space-X wasn't utilizing more of that available information... and two... these things must leave guys with conflicting emotions... maybe something like this... ohh man... sh!t... that sucks... ...followed by...  but holy crap... that explosion was unreal... did you see that... biggest I've ever seen... and three... of course Russia doesn't believe in self destruct explosives... you know what happens in a communist nation if you admit there any chance the project you are leading could fail... you would not be around long... that is for sure... finally another thing... although Russia has been known to come up with some great engineering technology... Russia was also known for significantly substandard production/manufacturing quality... hence... the worker pounding the angular velocity sensors into place in the wrong direction... this is a great example of the high level of 'idiot proofing' needed in Russia with people growing up learning... you get the same pay/chance for promotion regardless of how good (or bad) your work is.

Hi Tim!
Thanks for you excellent channel!
Awsome videos and explanations. They bring back to my memory the night Soyuz rocket launch failure while carrying ESA's Foton M-1 satellite in 2006. There are three videos and I truly believed you would include them. It is certainly not the greatest rocket wreckage, but it's a good example of how security issues must NOT be managed. If you see ESA N° 2 video you can see the launch and into 25 sec into flight, rocket got to a total shut down and at 40 secs. it blasted down after falling back on the pad (no "bye-bye button" either!). But watch that same ESA N° 2 video: sonic boom arrives just 1 second after the blast flash! According to my knowledge, as sound travels at 343 m/s, that is, ESA observers were at just 343 m (1,115 ft) from the site of disaster!!
Moreover, it's funny hearing a Russian officer, after everybody in ESA's team was still creeping on the ground, explaining what had happened: 'It's a failed launch. A launch failure. Rocket over...' what seemed to everyone all around something exquisitely evident!
And this is why we have Kerbal Space Program, to test our "good ideas". Also to see rockets explode, the explosions explode, and the fires started catch on fire. Ah, good times.

Very excellent video with explanation of failures.  This is the commentary lacking in many past videos of failures.  I remember many of these earlier failures in the 50s and 60s.  If I recall correctly, there were so many early failures of Titan I that the program was seriously considered too ambitious for the time and a duplication of the Atlas ICBM program.  It is quite amazing that Thor--and its successor vehicles based upon the Thor IRBM configuration--became one of the most reliable vehicles ever created for space.  Thor had its failures, too, but what was learned made it a prominent successor to all those improvements of the configuration which followed: Thor-Able, Thor-Able Star, Thor Agena B, Thor-Delta, Thrust-Augumented Thor and finally all the Delta vehicles to the current Delta IV.  Douglas Aircraft built a phenomenal design.

Regarding Ariane V, I have quite the anecdote.

First, just after the rocket explodes, you can hear the operator saying in French "All the parameters are nominal, trajectory is nominal"... Yeah, for sure...

Second, I happen to personally know one of the engineers which was part of the team that developed the control program for the turbopumps of Ariane V.
He said a lot of people knew that this test would fail, because of untenable deadline fixed for launch by the politicians. And it was an untested (due to time constraints)
Ariane IV guidance piece of software that ultimately caused the failure. As my friend said it (we are both Belgians) :
"The Belgians were in charge of the rocket [ground computer] until T-9, and of the self-destruct sequence. In between, that was the Frenchs. They lasted 53 seconds."

The N1's yield is kind of hard to pin down. Because the fuel and oxidizer were not initially mixed, estimates range from just shy of 7 kt (full detonation of the fuel supply, which would indeed be the largest artificial explosion in human history) down to 1 kt (estimated 15% fuel detonation, far behind several major ammunition explosions.) However, the 1 kt number doesn't count fuel that simply burned rather than strictly detonating. The air blast was certainly much stronger than a simple 1 kt explosion, but 85% of the fuel supply deflagrating in the presence of LOX is a much slower release of energy, which results in a lower peak pressure, so... this one is likely to just go down as a big question mark.
Still, it was unquestionably picked up by US seismic sensors as a possible nuclear test, so its spot at the top of this particular list is unchallenged.

Hi Tim, really enjoyed this collection of BOOMS, and as a 70 year old space geek almost from birth (my dad was an engineer with Rocketdyne from the early days of the Atlas program, and ran the qualification testing on the J-2 engine that powered the upper two stages of the Saturn 5) I learned a lot from it. But you did leave out one that I thought deserved to be included. It was the Titan 34D launch from Vandenberg on 18 April 1986, which turned into a huge toxic fireball only about 700 feet off the pad. Of course this was only a few months after the loss of Challenger, and the payload was the very last KH-9 Hexagon (aka "Big Bird") recon satellite, probably cost something like a billion dollars. Not only was the explosion much more spectacular than some you included, but it probably was one of the most expensive booms in history. Here are some links:

Being an ordnance engineer who designed flight destruct systems, I can tell you that the first rockets, like the first Atlas you show didn’t have the same type FTS Command Destruct Controller /Decoder we have today because the electronics were to big and couldn’t withstand the levels required (think glass vacuum tubes) to survive flight. (Thank you Apollo for all our modern tech).  The old systems used lanyard pull detonators, which fired during motor breakup.  They also used inertial destruct systems until the electronics got small enough and robust enough to survive.
Biggest lessons, don't use leftover Russian parts, don't down convert 64-bit numbers, and don't program flight controllers using BOTH metrics and imperial measurements.

Interesting note: the NK-33/AJ-26 engine that powered the original configuration of the Orbital Sciences Antares was a derivative of the NK-15 engine that powered the N-1 (which I suppose makes sense, considering the NK-33 was originally intended for a derivative of the N-1). The AJ-26 variant wasn't that much of a change - primarily just the control electronics were updated.

Also an interesting note: when the N-1 program was canceled, anything related to the program was ordered to be destroyed. Including the NK-33s that had been built. So why was Orbital able to use NK-33s in their Antares, 40-odd years after the N-1 program was shut down and all hardware destroyed? Well, some bureaucrat ensured that the engines were "lost," and subsequently stored them in a warehouse for a couple of decades until Western engineers finally heard of them in the 1990s. Aerojet would subsequently purchase several of these engines in the mid-1990s, but wouldn't find a market for them until Orbital came calling.

This means that the turbopump that failed had been sitting in a warehouse in substandard conditions for 40-odd years before ever seeing any LOX or RP1. And had been built by Soviet production staffs, working on a shoestring budget, for a rocket that was canceled before any other hardware could be built.

All I'm saying is, Orbital really shouldn't have been surprised that #7 happened.

Biggest non-nuclear explosion in history? Nope not even close. The November 27 1944 explosion at RAF Fauld where in excess of 3500 Tonnes of explosives detonated (in excess of 5000 tonnes of ordenence ranging from rifle ammunition to 4000lb thinwall bombs) was bigger, the Halifax explosion may have been bigger than Fauld, and there are a couple of possibilities for some even larger. http://www.amusingplanet.com/2016/09/the-fauld-explosion-crater-at-hanbury.html And yes I am aware that rocket fuel has a higher energy density than explosives but that energy is delivered over a far longer time period and therefore the intensity is lower. EG some explosives have a flame front burning at Mach 25+. PETN Det cord burns at about 6500m/s when it is not confined (faster when it is). RDX (a WWII era explosive) burns at closer to 8,000m/s so detonation 400m in diameter (approximate size of Fauld explosion) is going to take 0.05 seconds. Rocket fuel would take in excess of 10 times that causing only 1/5 of the overpressure at most.

The SpaceX COPV failure mode is described incorrectly.  The solid O2 damaging the carbon fiber overwrap didn't cause the helium tank to rupture.  It created friction which resulted in ignition of the carbon fiber in a pressurized pure O2 enviornment resulting in rapid combustion (not an explosion).  That led to the failure of the COPV and the continued rapid combustion.

11:16 I'm pretty sure oxygen doesn't expand when frozen. Rather the correct process would have been:
. oxygen froze between aluminum and carbon fiber of helium tank that became super chilled when some helium was released (otherwise it would have been at thermal equilibrium with oxygen, not colder)
. solid oxygen shrunk
. the micro-void back filled with additional oxygen that also froze
. solid oxygen unfroze when the helium bottle warmed up when being refilled
. some carbon fibers broke and shifted when oxygen expanded as it unfroze
. Heat from friction and carbon bonds breaking acted as ignition source, carbon as fuel, oxygen as oxidizer (no kidding /s)
. Helium tank also ruptured... Big Bada Boom

Note it was more the mistake of releasing some helium and then refilling while the tanks were submerged in oxygen that caused the problem, so SpaceX mainly needed to change their procedure more than design (although I think they probably addressed both issues).
